chapter.para: The &qemu; guest agent (GA) runs inside the &vmguest; and allows the &vmhost; to run commands in the guest operating system via &libvirt;. It supports many functions—for example, getting details about guest file systems, freezing and thawing file systems, or suspending or rebooting a guest.
&qemu; GA is included in the qemu-guest-agent package and is installed, configured, and activated by default on &kvm; virtual machines.

&qemu; GA is installed in &xen; virtual machines, but it is not activated by default. Although it is possible to use &qemu; GA with &xen; virtual machines, there is no integration with libvirt as described below for &kvm; virtual machines. To use &qemu; GA with &xen;, a channel device must be added to the &vmguest; configuration. The channel device includes a Unix domain socket path on the &vmhost; for communicating with &qemu; GA.

sect1.title: Running &qemu; GA commands
sect1.para: &qemu; GA includes many native commands that do not have direct &libvirt; counterparts. Refer to to find the complete list. You can run all of the &qemu; GA commands by using &libvirt;'s general purpose command qemu-agent-command:

sect1.title: &virsh; commands that require &qemu; GA
sect1.para: Several &virsh; commands require &qemu; GA for their functionality. Here are some of them:

listitem.para: Prints information about the guest from the guest's point of view.
Queries or changes the state of virtual CPUs from the guest's point of view.
Sets the password for a user account in the guest.
Shows a list of mounted file systems within the running domain.

sect1.title: Enhancing &libvirt; commands
sect1.para: If &qemu; GA is enabled inside the guest, a number of &virsh; subcommands have enhanced functionality when run in the agent mode. The following list includes only some examples of them. For a complete list, see the &virsh; manual page and search for the agent string.

varlistentry.term: virsh shutdown --mode agent and virsh reboot --mode agent

listitem.para: This method of shutting down or rebooting leaves the guest clean for its next run, similar to the ACPI method.
Instructs the guest to make its file system quiescent—to flush all I/O operations in the cache and leave volumes in a consistent state, so that no checks will be needed when they are remounted.
Changes the number of CPUs assigned to a guest.
Queries the &qemu; GA for the guest's IP address.
Prints information about the virtual CPU counts from the perspective of the guest.

The &virsh; manual page (man 1 virsh) includes descriptions of the commands that support the &qemu; GA interface.
